chapter.title: Understanding SystemTap Errors
chapter.para: This chapter explains the most common errors you may encounter while using SystemTap.

section.title: Parse and Semantic Errors
section.para: These types of errors occur while SystemTap attempts to parse and translate the script into C, prior to being converted into a kernel module. For example type errors result from operations that assign invalid values to variables or arrays.

formalpara.title: parse error: expected foo, saw bar
formalpara.para: The script contains a grammatical/typographical error. SystemTap detected type of construct that is incorrect, given the context of the probe.

formalpara.title: parse error: embedded code in unprivileged script
formalpara.para: The script contains unsafe embedded C code (blocks of code surrounded by %{ %}. SystemTap allows you to embed C code in a script, which is useful if there are no tapsets to suit your purposes. However, embedded C constructs are not be safe; as such, SystemTap warns you with this error if such constructs appear in the script.

section.para: If you are sure of the safety of any similar constructs in the script and are member of stapdev group (or have root privileges), run the script in "guru" mode by using the option -g (i.e. stap -g script).

formalpara.title: semantic error: type mismatch for identifier 'foo' ... string vs. long
formalpara.para: The function foo in the script used the wrong type (i.e. %s or %d). This error will present itself in , because the function execname() returns a string the format specifier should be a %s, not %d.

formalpara.title: semantic error: unresolved type for identifier 'foo'
formalpara.para: The identifier (e.g. a variable) was used, but no type (integer or string)could be determine. This occurs, for instance, if you use a variable in a printf statement while no other function in the script can assign a value to it.

formalpara.title: semantic error: Expecting symbol or array index expression
formalpara.para: SystemTap could not assign a value to a variable or to a location in an array. The destination for the assignment is not a valid destination. The following example code would generate this error:

formalpara.title: while searching for arity N function, semantic error: unresolved function call
formalpara.para: A function call or array index expression in the script used an invalid number of arguments/parameters. In SystemTap arity can either refer to the number of indices for an array, or the number of parameters to a function.

formalpara.title: semantic error: array locals not supported:
formalpara.para: The script used an array operation without declaring the array as a global variable (global variables can be declared after their use in Systemtap scripts). Similar messages appear if an array is used, but with inconsistent arities.

formalpara.title: semantic error: variable ’foo’ modiﬁed during ’foreach’
formalpara.para: The array foo is being modifed (being assigned to or deleted from) within an active foreach loop. This error also displays if an operation within the script performs a function call within the foreach loop.

formalpara.title: semantic error: probe point mismatch at position N, while resolving probe point foo
formalpara.para: SystemTap did not understand what the event or SystemTap function foo refers to. This usually means that SystemTap could not find a match for foo in the tapset library. The N refers to the column the error occurred in.

formalpara.title: semantic error: no match for probe point, while resolving probe point foo
formalpara.para: The events / handler function foo could not be resolved altogether, for a variety of reasons. This error occurs when the script contains the event kernel.function("blah"), and blah does not exist. In some cases, the error could also mean the script contains an invalid kernel file name or source line number.

formalpara.title: semantic error: unresolved target-symbol expression
formalpara.para: A handler in the script references a target variable, but the value of the variable could not be resolved. This error could also mean that a handler is referencing a target variable that is not valid at all in the context when it was referenced.

formalpara.title: semantic error: libdwﬂ failure
formalpara.para: There was a problem processing the debugging information. In most cases, this error results from the installation of a kernel-debuginfo RPM whose version does not match the probed kernel exactly. The installed kernel-debuginfo RPM itself may have some consistency / correctness problems.

formalpara.title: semantic error: cannot find foo debuginfo
formalpara.para: SystemTap could not find a suitable kernel-debuginfo at all.

section.title: Run Time Errors and Warnings
section.para: Runtime errors and warnings occur when the SystemTap instrumentation has been installed and is collecting data on the system.

formalpara.title: WARNING: Number of errors: N, skipped probes: M
formalpara.para: Errors and/or skipped probes occurred during this run. Both N and M are the counts of the number of probes that were not executed due to conditions such as too much time required to execute event handlers over an interval of time.

formalpara.title: division by 0
formalpara.para: The script code performed an invalid division.

formalpara.title: aggregate element not found
formalpara.para: An statistics extractor function other than @count was invoked on an aggregate that has not had any values accumulated yet. This is similar to a division by zero.

formalpara.title: aggregation overflow
formalpara.para: An array containing aggregate values contains too many distinct key tuples at this time.

formalpara.title: MAXNESTING exceeded
formalpara.para: Too many levels of function call nesting were attempted.

formalpara.title: MAXACTION exceeded
formalpara.para: The probe handler attempted to execute too many statements.

formalpara.title: kernel/user string copy fault at ADDR
formalpara.para: The probe handler attempted to copy a string from kernel or user space at an invalid address (ADDR.

formalpara.title: pointer dereference fault
formalpara.para: There was a fault encountered during a pointer dereference operation such as a target variable evaluation.
